awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Drawing from Theories of Justice to Respond to Online Harassment
awd_abstract_narration:
This award investigates how theories and models of justice can be designed into online systems for people and technology to more effectively and productively respond to online harassment. It develops approaches to respond to online harassment in ways that promote perceptions of fairness of process and outcome and reduce likelihood of future harassment by both the offender and the community. This research will provide Internet users with theoretically-informed strategies for responding to online offenses. It will also provide technology companies and policymakers with guidelines for promoting civility and inclusivity online. It will translate research results to the public through a web-based resource for Internet users and will produce a toolbox of educational resources that exposes students to the theories, methods, and open questions surrounding online harassment - a widespread and socially relevant problem in computing that has not been solved by existing systems. Currently, automated approaches such as keyword detection are plagued by errors that have counter-productive results, while social practices such as reporting demand exhaustive labor from victims. Both approaches rely on a model of criminal justice that seeks to identify and punish offenders for their offenses; however, this model breaks down in online environments where harassers can hide behind anonymous identities and lagging legal systems.

The work will first 1) audit existing site policies and practices for responding to online harassment and map those to theories of justice; and 2) investigate how Internet users assess and respond to harassment based on characteristics of the site, offender, post, and community. Then, it will propose and evaluate interventions that 3) promote perceptions of fairness in process and outcome in response to harassment; and 4) reduce likelihood of future harassment. Finally, it will provide a public-facing interactive tool that 5) trains Internet users to identify and improve their own orientations toward retribution online; and 6) provides educational content for high school and college students to learn theories, methods, and opportunities in the field of computing through a robust set of case studies in online harassment. This research employs a novel and potentially transformative vision for leveraging fundamental principles of justice, including fairness, transparency, proportionality, and reparation, into online interactions. This may be more effective than existing models because it is not as dependent on the ability to enact consequences for any given user. This project addresses numerous conceptual and technical challenges, including how to enact fair processes and proportionate outcomes in responses to online harassment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research project was to understand how justice theories can be incorporated into social media governance. The project considered whether retributive versus restorative frameworks would be effective and acceptable for users. It also explored how potential remedies might vary depending on the harms associated with types of online harassment.

The primary activities included a series of surveys measuring people's perceptions of harms associated with online harassment, their preferences for remedies, and how those perceptions and preferences varied by demographics. The project also supported interview studies and design activities focused on privacy, AI, and digital technologies.

In one of the project's earliest studies, we reflected on the limitations of current punitive approaches on social media platforms, such as banning users or removing harmful content, for addressing the needs of harassment victims. These methods often fail to address and repair the harm that victims may experience. We considered the addition of restorative justice approaches where offenders can be educated about appropriate behavior and where victims can have a voice in the process. The work emphasized that online harassment is not a one-size-fits-all issue and that offenses, harms, and remedies should be context-specific. It also demonstrated that preferences for remedies varied based on demographics. A key contribution of this work was the proposal of justice-oriented frameworks for addressing online harassment, an approach which has now been broadly taken up by other scholars and in industry practice.

Though this early work introduced restorative justice as an alternative framework for responding to online harassment, as the project advanced, it became clear that restorative justice approaches were likely to be appropriate and effective in only some cases. When online harassment was perceived as more severe (e.g. non-consensual content sharing) as compared to less severe (e.g. insults), people tended to prefer more punitive responses, like content removal and user bans. Preferences varied by group too; in general, people from marginalized backgrounds tended to prefer more punitive responses. This may be because these groups are more likely to experience harassment, and restorative processes may be less appropriate in those cases.

Notably, our study with youth showed that they were more likely to favor restorative approaches, especially apologies from offenders. They preferred private apologies over public ones, perhaps reflecting a desire for authentic engagement. Youth conflict is often interpersonal, involving people with whom they have existing relationships, and they may prefer not to punish peers.

While many of the project's studies focused on U.S.-based attitudes and preferences, we also explored how the U.S. compares to 14 other countries globally. Here we found that participants in non-U.S. countries reported higher perceptions of harm associated with online harassment as compared to U.S. participants. These differences were greatest in non-Western countries, such as Colombia, India, and Malaysia. One explanation for this difference is the role of reputational harm. In many non-Western countries, family reputation is especially important, and online behavior that might threaten that reputation was seen as harmful. This also likely explained why women across all 14 countries reported higher perceptions of harm than men, on average, especially regarding non-consensual image sharing. In many parts of the world, women may be judged or shamed for their presence online, and in some cases, this shaming comes from their own family members. While women preferred content removals and user bans in general, women also valued public apologies and revealing the identity of harassers. This highlights the importance of recognizing contextual and cultural differences in harms and remedies associated with online harassment.

This project laid the groundwork for using justice frameworks in social media governance. Many scholars have subsequently explored restorative and retributive justice theories in online contexts, building on work from this project. These ideas have also been explored in industry contexts where companies must make real-world decisions about how to respond to harmful behaviors. Work from this project has been cited in policy reports. The project supported the training and career development of multiple PhD students, Masters students, and undergraduate students.
